awd_titl_txt: Dissipative Phenomena in Effective Field Theories
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Riccardo Penco at Carnegie Mellon University. 

Dissipation gives rise to many interesting phenomena in Nature. It can also be a frustrating barrier to overcome on the path towards technological applications. Despite the important role that dissipation plays in many physical systems, it is often modeled phenomenologically rather than by following a systematic procedure based on fundamental principles. The overarching goal of this project is to develop a more systematic understanding of dissipation by exploiting modern theoretical techniques known as effective field theories. To this end, Professor Penco will tackle a variety of conceptual problems and concrete applications in two distinct areas: hydrodynamics and gravitational systems. This project is also expected to have broader societal impacts. An important outcome will be the advanced training of a postdoctoral researcher. This advances the national interest by directly contributing to the quality of the STEM workforce in the US. Professor Penco will also engage in outreach activities aimed at communicating scientific knowledge outside the typical classroom setting and promoting work in STEM fields as a viable career option. 

More technically, Professor Penco's work will build upon recent progress in dissipative hydrodynamics and explore how the recently uncovered symmetries of thermal states (BRST, KMS, supersymmetry) constrain the effective action of Goldstone modes of spontaneously broken spacetime symmetries. The spectrum of topics he plans to explore ranges from applied (e.g., fluids and superfluids) to formal (e.g., the Goldstone theorem at finite density and temperature). In the context of gravitational physics, Professor Penco will explore a variety of dissipative aspects in black-hole physics (e.g., quasi-normal modes, superradiance) which can play an important role both in astrophysics as well as in high-energy physics, particularly in the context of modified gravity and holography.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award funded research on a broad range of aspects centered around effective field theories (EFTs).  The main results of this projects are the following: (1) The discovery of a network of hidden symmetries of black hole perturbations. These symmetries are responsible for an otherwise puzzling property of black holes, namely the fact that they do not get "deformed" in the presence of weak external fields. Black holes are the only macroscopic objects with this property, and this behavior would seem to pose a naturalness problem at low-energies, where black holes can be described by a point-particle EFT. The newly discovered symmetries are what set black holes apart from everything else, and explain this curious behavior. (2) The discovery of a universal connection between EFT corrections to the entropy of a system and its extremality bound, i.e. the maximum amount of conserved quantities (charge, angular momentum) that an object can have for a given energy. This result has important applications for black hole physics and the weak gravity conjecture, but its universal nature means that it also applies to systems that can be studied in the laboratory. (3) The development of an EFT approach to magneto-elasticity, i.e. a low-energy description of the relevant collective excitations (phonons and magnons) in magnetic systems that display an elastic behavior. (4) The discovery of fractional soft limits in scattering amplitudes of phonons in solids. Soft limits are particular kinematic configuration of scattering processes where one of the particles involved has a momentum much smaller than that of all the other particles. For particles who energy vanishes at zero momentum, the scattering amplitude will typically also vanish in the soft limit, and in relativistic theories it always does so like an integer power of the small momentum. Phonons in solids are the first system discussed in the literature where the (4-point) scattering amplitude vanishes like a fractional power of the soft momentum. This could have interesting implications for the calculation of transport coefficients in condensed matter.
This award has also had significant broader impacts. The PI has played an active role in the  US Community Study on the Future of Particle Physics (Snowmass 2021) by co-authoring two reviews on aspects of EFTs. The PI also prepared a set of lecture notes on effective field theory methods that are publicly available at https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.16285. Furthermore, this award supported the advanced physics training of a postdoctoral scholar and provided research opportunities for two Physics Ph.D. students, thus increasing talent pool of the STEM workforce in the US.
